title: Jack Elsegood
text:
Barry "Jack" Elsegood (born 22 December 1973 in <a href="Sydney%20Australia">Sydney Australia</a>), is an Australian former professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer and now race driver.
Rugby League.
Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles.
A <a href="Manly-Warringah%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles</a> junior and an <a href="Australian%20Schoolboys%20rugby%20league%20team">Australian Schoolboys</a> representative in 1991, Elsegood was made his first grade debut for the Sea Eagles in the opening round of the <a href="1993%20NSWRL%20season">1993</a> against local rivals <a href="North%20Sydney%20Bears">North Sydney</a>. 1993 was actually to be Elsegood's best individual season at Manly. He played 22 games, scored 12 tries (including a memorable length of the field try in Manly's 36–10 Minor Semi-final loss to <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos">Brisbane</a> at the <a href="Sydney%20Football%20Stadium">Sydney Football Stadium</a>), as well as winning both the <a href="Dally%20M%20Awards">Dally M</a> <a href="List%20of%20Dally%20M%20Awards%20winners%231993">Rookie of the Year</a> and the Norwich Rising Star awards.
1994 was a down year for Elsegood. A shoulder injury suffered in Manly's successful <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Sevens">World Sevens</a> win in the pre-season would hamper him for the season and would eventually require surgery at seasons end. Unfortunately for Elsegood, who before the season was tipped as a bolter for the <a href="1994%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1994 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain and France</a>, the injury would also hamper his form and he only crossed for 4 tries for the year and he was subsequently overlooked for the <a href="Kangaroo%20Tour">Kangaroo Tour</a>.
Elsegood would continue to be a regular on the Manly wing in both <a href="1995%20ARL%20season">1995</a> and <a href="1996%20ARL%20season">1996</a>, though he missed Manly's Grand Final loss to the <a href="Canterbury%20Bulldogs">Sydney Bulldogs</a> in 1995 while he sat on an extended bench for Manly's 20–8 win over <a href="St%20George%20Dragons">St George</a> in the 1996 Grand Final but did not get to play on the day.
Sydney City Roosters.
After 4 years and 72 games for Manly, Elsegood signed with the <a href="Sydney%20City%20Roosters">Sydney City Roosters</a> from 1997. He would go on to play 77 games for the Roosters, crossing for 35 tries (10 more than at Manly).
After 149 games in 8 seasons, Elsegood retired from playing rugby league at the end of the <a href="2000%20NRL%20season">2000 NRL season</a>.
Rugby League career highlights.
† Did not play in Grand Final
Motor racing.
After retiring from football at the end of the 2000 season, he moved into property development and was a co-owner of Delmege Residential. In 2001 he had his first race in an HQ Holden and made his debut in the <a href="V8%20Ute%20Racing%20Series">V8 Ute Racing Series</a> in 2002. He won the Australian V8 Ute Championship in <a href="2009%20V8%20Utes%20season">2009</a> and has been runner up four times (2004, 2006, 2007 and 2010). Jack Elsegood is the grandson of <a href="Newtown%20Jets">Newtown Jets</a> legendary hardman <a href="Frank%20Farrell%20%28rugby%20league%29">Frank 'Bumper' Farrell</a>.
At the <a href="2007%20WPS%20Bathurst%2012%20Hour">2007 WPS Bathurst 12 Hour</a> race held at the famous <a href="Mount%20Panorama%20Circuit">Mount Panorama Circuit</a>, Elsegood finished 9th outright and 1st in Class D driving a <a href="Ford%20BF%20Falcon">Ford BF Falcon</a> XR8 alongside Chris Delfsma and multiple championship winning and twice <a href="Bathurst%201000">Bathurst 1000</a> winner <a href="John%20Bowe%20%28racing%20driver%29">John Bowe</a>.
Elsegood also made an appearance in the 2007 rugby league drama film "<a href="The%20Final%20Winter">The Final Winter</a>".
